description: The course focuses on the natural history of different wetland types including climate, geology, and,hydrology factors that influence wetland development Associated soil, vegetation, and wildlife characteristics and key ecological processes will be covered as well. Lectures will be supplemented with weekend wetland types, ranging from tidal salt marshes to non-tidal marshes, swamps, and glacial bogs in order to provide field experience in wetland identification, characterization, and functional assessment. Outside speakers will discuss issues in wetland seed bank ecology, federal regulation, and mitigation. Students will present a short paper on the ecology of a wetland animal and a longer term paper on a selected wetland topic. Readings from the text, assorted journal papers, government technical documents, and book excerpts will provide a broad overview of the multifaceted field of wetland study.
name: WETLANDS

values.comments:
The course focuses on the natural history of different wetland types including
climate, geology, and, hydrology factors that influence wetland development. Associated
soil, vegetation, and wildlife characteristics and key ecological processes are covered as
well. Lectures are supplemented with weekend wetland types, ranging from tidal salt
marshes to non-tidal marshes, swamps, and glacial bogs in order to provide field
experience in wetland identification, characterization, and functional assessment. Outside
speakers discuss issues in wetland seed bank ecology, federal regulation, and mitigation.
Students present a short paper on the ecology of a wetland animal and a longer term
paper on a selected wetland topic. Readings from the text, assorted journal papers,
government technical documents, and book excerpts provide a broad overview of the
multifaceted field of wetland study.
Many students reported that this was a “superb course.” In particular, students
noted that the “field trips were amazing.” Students found they were able to “witness
firsthand the conceptual underpinnings of the course,” which greatly helped their
learning. Some students wished there was a greater “focus on technical wetland
elements” instead of the amount of time spent on student presentations, which was
“somewhat excessive.”
Students overwhelmingly referred to Professor Willig as an “excellent instructor.”
One student described her as “a very engaged and engaging teacher… [with] unrivaled
enthusiasm and impressive knowledge of the subject matter she teaches.” One student
also noted she was “very supportive.”
Some students complained that information in the assigned readings “was rarely
brought up in class” and that the books were “not necessarily needed.”
